your
shaders. So, first and foremost, what is

in-house solution to distributed work.
So, whether you're compiling the editor
through UBT or you're using the editor
to compile shaders, UBA is there to help
facilitate remote execution.
So it is multiplatform in that we
support uh Mac, Linux and Windows
natively and it's applicable in both the
build farm and the local user contexts.
So at the end of 2023 we rolled this out
to our build farm and at the beginning
of 2024 we rolled this out to our end
users. So just engineers and developers
within Epic. So again, what that means
is whether you're a nightly job in the
CI doing a clean build of the game or
you're an engineer or someone else
working on the team trying to make a
better game, UBA is there to help you
rapidly get through your job. The last
important thing to note here at a high
level is that we use Unreal Horde as the
coordinator. So fundamentally we have a
remote execution system that allows you
to acquire resources from the compute

work. So it's important to note that
there's many features in Horde. You
should come and talk to me about them
after. Uh but you don't need to buy into
the whole ecosystem. You can just use
remote execution and get going with
UBA. So how did we deploy this at Epic?
So we use AWS spot instances for Linux
and Windows. So effectively Linux
instances running wine. This is great.
We have one pool that can service both
platforms and we have two primary pools
that we use. So the build farm helpers
and the end user helpers. And the reason
that we've broken these out into two
different pools is that they have very
different usage characteristics and we
want to be able to tune those
accordingly. Uh next up uh we self-host
for Mac. So 60 nodes that serve both the
bill farm and end users. And finally
we've enabled remote linking. So what
this is is UBT allows you to take your
link actions and execute them remotely
through UBA. Now this works best for
non-monolithic so Unreal editor and it
is Windows only at this
point. So we've got the highle idea how
we've rolled it out at Epic. Let's look
at some important details that make UBA
special.
So any distributed work system needs to
answer a really important question which
is when you're a remote helper and
you're trying to execute an action like
cl.exe just compiling what's the
totality of inputs that you need on that
helper to even run the command. So
that's to say in this example what
header files or extra C++ source files
or whatever do I need on this machine so
that I can even run this. So UBA
determines this by tying into uh system
level calls. So open file as an example
on Windows. So that when we run the
action, we can intercept those and
coordinate with the initiating machine
as needed. So this is also important for
outputs. So cl.exe is going to output an
object file. We also intercept that so
that we can coordinate the outputs back
to the initiating machine. This is a
really important detail. It's used all
throughout UBA and it's just to
reinforce it. There's no costly
pre-processing on the initiating machine
to decide all the inputs and then try
and send those all over in bulk. It's
all dynamic from the perspective of the
helper. So mechanically speaking on
Microsoft or pardon me on Windows we use
Microsoft detours for uh Mac OS we use
dibb interposing and for Linux we use
pix
interposing. So we've got an important
detail now in our back pocket. Let's
have a look at the overall program flow.
So we're going to start on the top left
as the compile agent and let's just say
we're compiling Unreal Editor as an
example. So what we do is we issue the
command to UBT and UBT will go and
create the action graph. So this is the
collection of all the actions that we
need to run through in order to produce
the binary. So then we take that and
then we issue a compute task to Horde
server. So coming into there. So with
horde server we have the remote
execution enabled off goes well and then
the next step that we do is we upload
our UBA binaries to the horde server. So
this is a really important detail for
UBA and what it does is it ensures that
we don't have to go through our entire
compute cluster and make sure we have
the perfect version that we're using of
UBA deployed everywhere. So we we solve
that problem by this particular step.
So once that upload is complete, the
horde server will start allocating
resources to use for this job. And these
can be new or just uh pre-existing in
the pool. So once we have the horde
agents spun up, we will then uh assign
those horde agents to the lease for the
job that I've requested. And now that
horde agent is going to download the UBA
binaries that I uploaded in the previous
step. So once that's done, it will run
UBA and then we'll get a peer-to-peer
connection established between the
initiating machine and the helper
machine. So now we do all the input and
output coordination using that OS level
intercept that I discussed before and
it's compressed in both directions. It's
also important to note that you can
enable encryption here as you so
choose. So one last important detail
before I move from this slide is you see
we just get a bunch of agents. But how
many agents do we get, Julian? So, UBA
is designed to go incredibly wide and if
you have enough build actions, you can
use the entire compute cluster if you
want, but your colleagues will probably
not like you too much. Um, so UBA
expresses some really important
configuration points for how wide we go.
So, for code compilation and shader
compilation, you have two of the same
controls. So the first is limiting how
many cores you use on the individual
agent. So you can use max CPU on the
code side as an example. But more
importantly you can constrain how many
CPUs and cores you use through the
entire session. So this would be the the
particular configuration that you use to
make sure that you don't take
everything. Um yeah. So now that we know
how we can control the breadth of

three times improvement in speed. So we

down to around 5 minutes for this build.
So that's a pretty massive win.
It's important to note that we do have
some cloud efficiencies here. So UBA has
an understanding of AWS as so
availability zones. So what it will do
is it will promote one of the nodes to
act as a cache for the other items in
the job. So now as the initiator you
don't need to have all these connections
to all these different helpers consuming
all your bandwidth. The node will take
